textline.text: Allyson Stokes
Department of Sociology, University of Texas at Austin, Austin, TX, 78712
Phone: (647) 924–2055 Email: allyson.stokes@utexas.edu Website: http://aejstokes.github.io
EDUCATION
2013 Ph.D. Sociology. McMaster University. Hamilton, Ontario.
2009 M.A. Sociology. McMaster University. Hamilton, Ontario.
2007 B.A. (Honours) Sociology. Memorial University. St. John’s, Newfoundland.
2006 Certificate in Criminology. Memorial University. St. John’s, Newfoundland.
PROFESSIONAL APPOINTMENTS
2014-Present SSHRC Postdoctoral Fellow, Department of Sociology, University of Texas at
Austin, Austin, Texas.
2013-2015 Visiting Scholar, Department of Knowledge Integration, University of Waterloo,
Waterloo, Ontario.
AREAS OF SPECIALIZATION
Social Inequality, Work, Culture, Gender, Qualitative Methods, Sociological Theory
PUBLICATIONS
Refereed Journal Articles
Allyson Stokes. 2015. “The Glass Runway: How Gender and Sexuality Shape the Spotlight in
Fashion Design.” Gender & Society, 29: 219-243.
Book Chapters
Tina Fetner, Allyson Stokes, and Carrie B. Sanders. 2015. “Institution Building and the
Religious Right: Lessons from U.S. and Canadian History.” Chapter 3 in Howard Ramos and
Kathleen Rodgers, eds. Protest and Politics: The Promise of Social Movement Societies.
Vancouver, BC: University of British Columbia Press.
Revise and Resubmit
Allyson Stokes and John McLevey. “From Porter to Bourdieu: The Evolving Speciality
Structure of Canadian Sociology in Comparative Perspective, 1966-2013.” (Revise and resubmit
from Canadian Review of Sociology)
John McLevey, Allyson Stokes, and Amelia Howard. “The Uneven Influence of Pierre Bourdieu
in Canada.” In Thomas Medvetz and Jeff Sallaz, eds. The Oxford Handbook of Pierre Bourdieu.
Oxford: Oxford University Press. (Revise and resubmit)
Under Review
Allyson Stokes. “Fashioning Gender: The Gendered Logics of Careers in Culture
Industries.” (Under review at Social Currents)
Manuscripts in Preparation
Allyson Stokes. “The Smokescreen of Glamour: Cultural Contradictions in Creative Work.”
Allyson Stokes. “Cultural Chameleons: Diversity and Inequality in Cultural Production.”
Allyson Stokes, John McLevey, and Neil McLaughlin. “Legitimation and Canonization Over
Time.”
Other Publications
2015. Allyson Stokes. “Women in the Culture Industries.” Work in Progress (Blog of the
American Sociological Association, Section on Organizations, Occupations, and Work) http://
workinprogress.oowsection.org/2015/03/18/women-in-the-culture-industries/
2015. Allyson Stokes. “The Glass Runway.” Gender & Society Blog. https://
gendersociety.wordpress.com/2015/04/10/the-glass-runway/
2013. Allyson Stokes. “Designer Profile: Gabriel Baradee.” SemiotiX: Design, Style, and
Fashion. http://fashion.semiotix.org/2013/02/gabriel-baradee-a-profile-in-fashion/
HONOURS AND AWARDS
2014 Nominee, Alice Wilson Award, The Royal Society of Canada.
2014 Outstanding Graduating Student Award, Canadian Sociological Association.
2014-2016 Postdoctoral Fellowship, SSHRC, $90 000 ($40, 500 per annum for two years).
2010–2013 Joseph-Armand Bombardier Canada Graduate Scholarship, Category A SSHRC
Doctoral Scholarship, $105, 000 ($35,000.00 per annum for three years).
2012 Yates Scholarship, McMaster University, $500.
2010–2011 Ontario Graduate Scholarship, $15,000.00. (declined)
2009–2013 PhD Graduate Scholarship, McMaster University, $52,000.00. Declined. ($10,000
replaced by Ontario Graduate Fellowship in 2009–2010, replaced by SSHRC CGS 2010–2013)
2009–2010 Ontario Graduate Fellowship, $12,000.00. Sociology Department Top-Up, $3,000
(declined).
2008 MA Graduate Scholarship, McMaster University, $6,000.00. (declined).
2007 University Medal for Academic Excellence in Sociology, Memorial University.
2006 Newfoundland and Labrador Hydro Scholarship, Memorial University. $1,000.
2005 Edna-Baird Stevenson Scholarship in Women’s Studies, Memorial University. $500.
2004-2007 Dean’s List, Faculty of Arts, Memorial University.
INVITED TALKS
2014. “Work-Family Conflict Among Cultural Workers.” Wilfred Laurier University.
2014. “The Glass Runway: How Gender and Sexuality Shape the Spotlight in Fashion Design.”
Denison University College.
CONFERENCE ACTIVITY / PARTICIPATION
Conference Sessions Organized
June 2015. “Sociology of Culture I: Theorizing Creativity and Cultural Production.” 2015
Annual Meeting of the Canadian Sociological Association, University of Ottawa, Ottawa, ON.
June 2015. “Sociology of Culture II: Collective Memory and Representations of Place.” 2015
Annual Meeting of the Canadian Sociological Association, University of Ottawa, Ottawa, ON.
June 2015. “Sociology of Culture III: Creative Fields and Media Industries.” 2015 Annual
Meeting of the Canadian Sociological Association, University of Ottawa, Ottawa, ON.
June 2015. “Sociology of Culture IV: Culture and Action in Everyday Life.” 2015 Annual
Meeting of the Canadian Sociological Association, University of Ottawa, Ottawa, ON.
June 2015. “Culture and Inequality I.” 2015 Annual Meeting of the Canadian Sociological
Association, University of Ottawa, Ottawa, ON.
June 2015. “Culture and Inequality II.” 2015 Annual Meeting of the Canadian Sociological
Association, University of Ottawa, Ottawa, ON.
June 2014. “Creative Industries and Cultural Workers.” 2014 Annual Meeting of the Canadian
Sociological Association, Brock University, St. Catherine’s, ON.
Papers Presented
August 2015. “The Gendered Organization of Work-Life Boundaries in the Fashion Industry.”
Presented at the 2015 annual meeting of the American Sociological Association, Chicago, IL.
June 2015. “Fashioning Gender: The Gendered Organization of Careers in Culture Industries.”
Allyson Stokes. Presented at the 2015 annual meeting of the Canadian Sociological Association,
University of Ottawa, Ottawa, ON.
August 2014. “The Glass Runway: How Gender and Sexuality Shape the Spotlight in Fashion
Design.” Allyson Stokes. Presented at the 2014 annual meeting of the American Sociological
Association, San Francisco, CA.
May 2014. “The Invisible Colleges of Sociology in Canada: a Network Analysis, 1995-2014.”
Allyson Stokes and John McLevey. Presented at the 2014 annual meeting of the Canadian
Sociological Association, Brock University, St. Catherine’s, ON.
August 2013. “Work Horses and Show Ponies: Processes of Cultural Devaluation in the Fashion
Industry.” Presented at the 2013 annual meeting of the American Sociological Association, New
York City, NY.
June 2013. “The Glass Runway: How Gender and Sexuality Influence Male Advantage in the
Cultural Field of Fashion Design.” Presented at the 2013 annual meeting of the Canadian
Sociological Association, University of Victoria, Victoria, BC.
June 2013. “Slippery Slopes to Non-Monogamies: Regulating the Undesirable Outcome of
Polygamy.” Melanie Heath and Allyson Stokes. Presented at the 2013 annual meeting of the
Sexualities Studies Association, University of Victoria, Victoria, BC.
August 2012. “Shifting Attitudes Toward Homosexuality: When, Where and Why?” Tina Fetner,
Neal Caren, Allyson Stokes, and Gerald Bierling. Crossing Boundaries, Workshopping
Sexualities Conference, organized by the Sexualities Section of the ASA, Denver, CO.
June 2012. “Making Sense of Separate Spheres: How Fashion Workers Construct and Negotiate
Meaning Around Time, Work, and the Family.” Presented at the 2012 annual Qualitative
Analysis Conference, Memorial University, St. John’s, NL.
June 2012. “Work-Family Balance: The Influence of Field Dynamics on Workers Experience
Among Employees in the Fashion Industry.” Presented at the 2012 annual Work and Family
Researcher Network Conference, New York City, NY.
June 2012 “Working Women in the Fashion Industry: Inequalities of Time Pressure and New
Forms of Multitasking.” Presented at the 2012 annual meeting of the Canadian Sociological
Association, Waterloo University, Waterloo, ON.
May 2012. “Institution Building and the Religious Right: Lessons from U.S. and Canadian
History.” Tina Fetner, Allyson Stokes and Carrie B. Sanders. Presented at A Social Movement
Society? Possibilities and Realities Workshop, Ottawa, ON.
April 2012. “Fashioning Time, Designing Boundaries: Time Use, Work-Life Balance, and
Inequality in the Field of Fashion.” Presented at the annual Jane Synge Memorial Conference,
McMaster University, Hamilton, ON.
Aug 2011 “Tool Kits and Time Lines: Temporal Cultures in the Lives of Students and Workers.”
Presented at the 2011 meeting of the American Sociological Association, Las Vegas, NV.
May 2011 “Doing Time: Time as a Form of Culture in Action” Presented at the 2011 annual
Qualitative Analysis Conference, Wilfred Laurier University, Brantford ON.
Feb 2011 “Settled and Unsettled Times: Comparing the Temporal Toolkits of Students and
Workers.” Presented at the 2010 annual meeting of the Eastern Sociological Society,
Philadelphia, PA.
June 2010 “Motion Pictures and Moral Panics: Ideological Representations of HIV/AIDS in
Film, 1981-2003.” Presented at the 2010 annual meeting of the Canadian Sociological
Association, Concordia University, Montreal, QC.
May 2010 (Previous version) “Motion Pictures and Moral Panics: Ideological Representations of
HIV/AIDS in Film, 1981-2003.” Presented at the 2010 annual Qualitative Analysis Conference,
Wilfred Laurier University, Brantford, ON.
May 2009 “Globalization, the State, and Organizations: The Case of International Film Co-
Productions and Canada’s Genie Awards.” David Young and Allyson Stokes. Presented at the
2009 meeting of the Canadian Sociological Association, Carleton University, Ottawa, ON.
TEACHING EXPERIENCE
2013 Teaching Assistant
Perspectives on Social Inequality, Department of Sociology, McMaster University.
2009-2011 Teaching Assistant
Classical and Contemporary Sociological Theory, Department of Sociology, McMaster
University.
2008–2009 Teaching Assistant
Classical and Contemporary Sociological Theory, Department of Sociology, McMaster
University.
RESEARCH EXPERIENCE
2012-2013 Research Assistant
Melanie Heath, Department of Sociology, McMaster University. “Harm or Right? Polygamy’s
contested Terrain Within and Across Borders.” Funded by SSHRC
2011-2012 Research Assistant
Tina Fetner, Department of Sociology, McMaster University. “Economic Inequality and
Prejudice in Cross-National Perspective.” Funded by SSHRC.
2008–2010 Research Assistant
David Young, Department of Sociology, McMaster University. “Cultural Globalization and the
Genie Awards.” Funded by SSHRC.
EXTRA TRAINING
June 2011. Hierarchical Linear Models. Inter-University Consortium for Political and Social
Research (ICPSR), held at University of Massachusetts, Amherst
April 2011. NYLON Workshop. “Cultures of Circulation.” SSHRC Funded. Ottawa, ON
SERVICE TO PROFESSION
Organizer and Liaison, Sociology of Culture / Cultural Sociology Research Cluster, Canadian
Sociological Association
Peer Reviewing: Gender & Society, Sociology Compass
DEPARTMENTAL / UNIVERSITY SERVICE
University of Texas at Austin
2014-Present Member, Ethnography Lab
McMaster University
2012-2013 Peer Mentoring Committee, Department of Sociology.
2012 Admissions Committee, Department of Sociology.
2010-2011 Welcome Day Committee, Department of Sociology.
2009–2012 Peer Mentor, Department of Sociology.
2009-2010 Selection Committee, Department of Sociology.
2009–2010 Co-Organizer, Jane Synge Memorial Conference, Department of Sociology.
2008–2010 Co-Organizer, Culture and Politics workshop, Department of Sociology.
PROFESSIONAL MEMBERSHIPS AND AFFILIATIONS
Canadian Sociological Association
American Sociological Association
Sociologists for Women in Society
REFERENCES
Christine Williams, Professor, Department of Sociology, University of Texas at Austin, Austin,
TX, USA, 78712, cwilliams@austin.utexas.edu
Tina Fetner, Associate Professor, Department of Sociology, McMaster University, Hamilton ON,
Canada, L8S 4M4, tina.fetner@mcmaster.ca
Melanie Heath, Associate Professor, Department of Sociology, McMaster University, Hamilton
ON, Canada, L8S 4M4, mheath@mcmaster.ca
